title: In Gamble v. United States, will the Supreme Court overrule the "separate sovereign" exception to the Double Jeopardy Clause?
preds: After recent decisions dealing with state/federal relationships (although they were about entirely different topics), I'm adjusting my forecast down 1 point to 10%. Very little movement on this because the Court's reasoning hasn't been strictly in favor of federal supremacy in all situations.
It's hard to imagine this court siding with an African American male convicted of a crime - particularly since it will be much easier to simply let the lower court's ruling stand.
I believe SCOTUS will rule against Terance Gamble in this matter.
Unlikely to make such great distinction of state and federal judicial power
Two justices with differing philosophies and styles have already gone on record for wanting to overturn the separate sovereigns exemption. This is a good solid case with little to muddy the water.
Supreme court does not want to reverse a ruling or help a criminal
The current Supreme Court is philosophically rooted in precedent.
Theoretically, this would give the conservative justices fits. But since this happens to be a guns issue, contortions are likely.
This could set precedent to undermine state and or federal powers in other areas

After the recent rulings in the death penalty cases, J. Gorsuch seems to be positioning himself as someone who's tough on criminals. I don't think his vote is a lock on this one, even with his originalist leanings. Reduces the likelihood by 4%.

After reading the oral arguments, I don't see how this gets five votes. Even with the previous arguments that some Justices have made for overturning the separate sovereigns exception to the Fifth Amendment and the hypotheticals they brought up, the initial skepticism they had of Gamble's position seems strong. J. Ginsburg clearly thinks they should overturn it, and J. Thomas has previously written about overturning. J. Gorsuch got a little closer to Gamble's position with the questions about federalism, so in a best case for Gamble, three...maybe four if J. Kavanaugh goes along. But J. Kavanaugh seems like a long shot for them. I think it's 6-3 or 7-2.

On its own, Gamble v. United States doesn't seem to meet the standards for overturning the precedent of separate sovereigns. The early amicus curiae briefs argue that there are a number of areas of overlapping jurisdiction that could be remedied by overruling the separate sovereign exception, but the later amicus curiae briefs and the questions posed by the court indicate serious problems of sovereignty and social justice that would need to be dealt with. My forecast of 6% reflects the possibility that five of the justices would concur on overruling the separate sovereign exception for different political and ideological reasons. Ideological reasons could include the interpretation that the separate sovereigns exception is not embodied in the text of the constitution. Political reasons could include the idea that states could effectively nullify federal laws by defining different punishments for certain crimes on a state level, and trying those crimes in state courts before they could be tried in federal court.

The transcript of the oral argument suggests that only Gorsuch is a strong yes.  Thomas did not even ask a question.  Justices Kegan, Breyer, Ginsburg, Kavenaughand Sotomayor seem to be no's.  Alito and Roberts are probable no's.  Hence, it is not like to be overruled.

Probably not.  Too much water under the bridge.  I think the case is much more likely to be used to create a framework for the current court to decide and marginally decrease the relative weight of originalist doctrine.  The Petitioner has a sound argument that the Court hasn't followed the original intent of the clause, and has assiduously avoided that debate in its past decisions, but won't find those reasons sufficient to overturn 150 years of precedent.

There needs to continue to be some theoretical safeguard against jury nullification and/or the discovery of significant new evidence (Bruno Magli's for example).  But "if it ain't broke don't fix it" applies here.
Tough call, but a blanket abolishment of separate sovereignty does not seem plausible.
They will sadly leave this as it is.

This is a conservative SCOTUS who don't change things without big reasons, and bizarre as the argument about 'separate sovereigns' looks to non-Americans, the presumption will be for no change, or let it expire. It would take a big point of law to make a shift likely: however, these things do happen, so some possibility must remain.
the original separate sovereign logic is weak as against the principal of double jeopardy, but this supreme court may be too conservative to over rule.
This is not otherwise a great case.  I would expect a successful case to cover a violation that was overly broad for one level.

De minimis non curat lex, and Gamble is about as minimus a citizen as one could find. Separate Sovereignty may go down in flames some day, but it will take a far larger and noisier case than this one to bring that about.
conservative court may go with the double jeopardy
There is a vague, very small chance of Sotomayor, Breyer, Ginsburg, Gorsuch, and Thomas voting to do this, but the other four are out of play and Sotomayor is very dubious, so it's highly unlikely.
Scotus oral arguments & analysis from scotusblog point to retaining the dual sovereign precedent
Ruling to the side of precedent.
SCOTUS would have to over turn previous precedent. The court is run by hard line conservatives. Conservatives like harsh punishments

Just a fascinating case which the potential to surprise, and it has an under tow of States Rights verus Federal Overreach, enough so that my circles took notice of it without me mentioning it. 18% is a tad low. Moving to 25%.

Given his predecessors Harlan Powell O'connor ,I would expect that there will be no radical changes or reappraisal of the application of the double jeopardy clause to States.

2. States have their own Bill's of rights 
3. Enforcement would be problematic when applied to state sentence enhancement schemes 
4.I will now actually read the briefs  I have tried to make a forecast about this based on my limited knowledge as a State Supreme Court  law clerk back in 1979 and the cases written thereafter. 
Happy Thanksgiving Mr.Chief Justice John Roberts and the best of health and happiness to you all State and Federal Judges your families and staffs
In my opinion,  we already have exceptions to " no double jeopardy."
I see this as a higher probability for what should be a minimal probability event, given the more conservative nature of the court and possible overly strict interpretation of federalism.

With this particular Court, I'm skeptical that they will not cross jurisdictional lines that have traditionally been held between states and federal jurisdictions. While the court is conservative, it has also been very activist under Chief Justice Roberts. The trend has been to assert more Federalist positions - in other words, leaning toward taking powers to the government where those powers are convenient for conservatives.

If i understood correctly they are both the same charge. Gamble v us is a single state act. A few related cases that I read: Abatte v us was an interstate act. Heath v us was two separate acts. Murder in georgia and kidnapping in Alabama.  With that noted the issue of PR v Sanchez Valle (Worth a read. Discussion on the origin of authority.) steps in as Alabama territory was created by the federal government in 1817. Though it was created from an original colony it was created by the federal government. The government of Alabama did not exist before the federal government and draws its original formation from it. 
Though to maintain equality it would be best not to differentiate between original colonies and former territories on matters of justice.
New SCOTUS composition will bias toward more punitive opinions.

The Supremes have and easy and comfortable one with this case. 
Other settled cases assures the outcome as the District affirmation.

Good day,
the law is clear on page 14 of the brief,  The  text  of  the  Double  Jeopardy  Clause  of  the  Fifth    Amendment    provides    that    “No    person    shall . . . be 
subject  for  the  same  offense  to  be  twice  put in jeopardy of life or limb.” The Clause admits of no    distinctions    based    on    the    identity    of    the    prosecuting     entity.  To  the contrary,  it  unambiguously   protects   each   “person” from     duplicative prosecutions
—regardless of their source " the main ideal is the part where the person is protected from and I quote:  "To  the contrary,  it  unambiguously   protects   each   “person” from     duplicative prosecutions
—regardless of their source "
 this line should prove double Jeopardy by the federal government as the state had already charged, convicted, sentience and incarcerated the subject.
The judges know they are there to administrate the law not write it congress writes the law.

Taken in into account @lsgold7 argument that it would declare California 3 strikes as unconstitutional, and his stellar law credential, and his connections, I am lowering the prediction pending oral argument.
I had to figure out myself why CA 3 strike law would be affected by this decision. I felt reading lsgold7 was like reading Justice Breyer... It went over my head as someone who had only a very rudimentally understanding of the law (only took 1 introductory law class). So, here is what I understand: If double jeopardy means once a crime is tried and sentence served, you cannot use it as basis to put harsher sentence to the 3rd offense, otherwise you are retrying the first and second offense.  Once again, it flew over my head and I don't understand, or grossly misunderstood the implication of this case toward California's "3 strike you are out" law. (*1) So, explain it to me please. (*1) for those not living in California, the state has a law that says if you committed two crimes, the third one would have to be served full term, no early parole, no early commuting, no reduction of jail time.  By the way, the law was passed by Republicans (back when such a beast existed in California) and Democrats were against it, because it heavily affected minorities. Also, non-violent crimes such as possession of drug (by a drug addict) counts toward the "three strikes".
Test 7, hmmm, double jeopardy violates the Constitution. Good chance originalists will limit only state OR feds to prosecute
Following @ttltran on this. Setting at 100 until after oral argument. Re-eval then.

@JMR2017.

Justices Ginsburg and Thomas agreed on looking for a case to overrule the double sovereign doctrine. As textualists and originalists, Justices Gorsuch and Kavanaugh probably will side with Ginsburg and Thomas, because the double soverign thing was invented by the Court, while the double jeopardy clause is written in the Constitution. I can't see any reason why all five remaining Justices will form a majority. In fact, it is very likely Justice Alito will join Ginsburg et al. as well. The only reason why prediction is not set to 100% is because oral argument has not been heard, and there is always a technical detail that can derail the petitioner's argument.

People are all over the map on this.  First, I think that this is an early opportunity to reinforce the idea that the Court in fact honors precedent and stare decisis.  When they overturn established principles for ideological reasons, it is always good to have other settings where stare decisis is honored.    There is a case for these sovereign separations.
too many precedents and history to support "sovereign separation"

Fascinating cases, actually.    The Supreme court has granted more "pauper" cases than I can ever recall seeing 5-6 in the last granting, usual is what 1-2? I like the idea of the supreme court going back to civilian roots - it argues against federal overreach.  Going back to this quesiton particularly.   The constitution is pretty explicit.  You shall not try a defendant twice for the same crime. 
Around 150 years ago, out of whole cloth, they invented the separate sovereigns exception.  However, the separate sovereigns was only binding on the federal government until 1969.  Early courts, and English common law absolutely prevented double prosecution - and the modern ruling has undergone challenge after challenge.  The issue here is that we are trammeling the right of finality.  The argument against double jeopardy is a right and defense for the individual against the government.  Four justices were needed to grant certiori - 5 are needed to prevail.  Interestingly,  Ginzburg and Thomas were in favor of granting a similar cert in 2013, and again in 2016. 
  And the ACLU has long been against this double jeopardy.  This could see an alignment between the ultra liberal and the textualist (originalist judges).  Something like Ginzberg, Thomas, Alito Kavanaugh.  Blueford v Arkansas  Kagan, Sotomayer,  & Ginzburg argued that double jeopardy applied.  Strange bedfellows indeed - usually the liberal wing advances the powers of federalism.  But in this case, it sure looks as if the liberal wing prevails picking up at least some of the textualists, being able to get a 6:3. Arguments against - there would be huge rafts of cases where the defendants would be let go, and perhaps sue for damages. 
  The court may shy away for this reason.  The court may wish to explore midway positions; trying to refine or correct the two sovereign doctrine.   Enumerating a standard seems very difficult to me.  OTOH:  This Court has not hesitated to restore constitutional protections that have narrowed beyond the Framers’ intent.  See, e.g., Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 60 (2004) (overturning a Confrontation Clause precedent that “depart[ed] from [its] historical principles”).  In such cases, the Court has stressed the importance of “provid[ing] at a minimum the degree of protection [the Constitution] afforded when it was adopted.”  Jones, 132 S. Ct. at 953 (Fourth Amendment).  This case gives the Court an ideal opportunity to reconsider whether the Double Jeopardy bar protects defendants subjected to state and federal prosecutions for the same crime.  Powerful arguments for the textualists.  Reverse.  55%
I know nothing about legal matters but why would they even agree to hear it if not for reversing?

This is a well-established principle.  A virulently partisan justice or two may vote to overturn it in order to protect M. Petits-Doigts from state prosecutors, but there is still sufficient integrity on the Court to preclude this result.
